Award.AwardTitle: HBCU DCL: EAGER Collaborative Engineering of a Biodegradable Polymer for Treatment of Various Water Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1740463
Clark

Presently, less than 1% of all the water on earth is freshwater readily available for human use. With increased human activities resulting in water contamination from industrial effluent, urban runoff, contaminated spills, and wastewater treatment discharges, there is a need for the development of more innovative and feasible solutions to provide sustainable methods to treat various types of contaminated water sources. This proposal seeks to develop controlled release biodegradable polymers for treatment of surface water, groundwater, and wastewater systems. The polymers will treat contaminated waters without the need for external power, equipment, or additional chemicals while only producing minimal biodegradable by-products.

This project is focused on the fundamental understanding of controlled release chemical-oxidant polymers to treat various source waters. Furthermore, new oxidants will be investigated for their ability to improve and optimize this treatment delivery mechanism. The ease of implementation would be transformative for those who maintain water quality in the fields of engineering, water resources, sustainability, environmental science, and public health. The proposed research plan explores both disinfection of microorganisms and oxidation of contaminants collected in the state of Florida. The development of the controlled release biodegradable polymer will be based on a patent developed by the Co-PI and modified for treatment of physical, chemical, and biological contamination of water sources. The novelty of this method is not only in sustainable remediation and treatment of various water contaminants; but also adding to the knowledge base to provide a more comprehensive understanding of oxidant release in water treatment. The research will be a collaboration between two leading Historically Black College & Universities (HBCUs), Florida AM University and North Carolina A&T, and run by students and faculty from groups traditionally underrepresented in the engineering research field. The proposed work will not only support graduate students who are traditionally underrepresented in the STEM fields, especially engineering, but it would also provide opportunity to help inspire undergraduates to purse both graduate studies and careers in these fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to an increased number of polluted water and wastewater systems within the United States, more innovative and feasible solutions must be explored to address contamination due to industrial effluent, urban runoff, agricultural waste, contaminated spills, and wastewater. To address this need, the EArly- concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) entitled ?EAGER Collaborative Engineering of a Biodegradable Polymer for Treatment of Various Water Systems? was implemented.  Funded by the National Science Foundation, the proposed work sought to provide novel science and engineering results and a potentially transformative environmentally sustainable water remediation technique that would benefit current society and provide solutions for environmental challenges in the future. The research focuses on the development and testing of a controlled release biodegradable polymers (CRBP) for treatment of contaminated water. The studied CRBP was based on a patented system developed by the co-PI (Dr. Stephanie Luster-Teasley, North Carolina A&T State University) and modified during this study to gain more information related to its potential to treat contaminated water in the lab of the PI (Dr. Clayton J. Clark II, Florida A&M University).  In the novel implementation of this CRBP technology, the research focused on examining the effectiveness in water treatment of the oxidant, potassium permanganate (KMnO4), after its encapsulation in the biodegradable polymer, polycaprolactone (PCL), in varying amounts.  These variations were designed and tested for diffusion kinetics of the oxidant into water as it was to degrade water-based contaminants. Another novel aspect of the studied KMnO4 embedded in PCL systems included the absence of any chemical or contaminant residual or the need for external power or equipment for the process.  The results of the research have the potential to improve treatment to produce safe potable water with the capacity to reduce potential environmental, health and safety risks to the public in the remediation of various water sources.

The intellectual merit for this research increased the fundamental understanding and provided a more comprehensive examination of the controlled release material of an established chemical oxidant embedded within a polymer for treatment of various water sources.  Furthermore, varying oxidant combinations were investigated for their ability to improve and optimize this treatment delivery mechanism. Specifically, it was noted that the release of potassium permanganate (KMnO4) from polycaprolactone (PCL) was shown to diffusive at similar rates as the oxidant's diffusion from other waxy polymers.  The benefit of it being released from PCL is that this polymer is more apt to easily biodegrade in water.  It was also determined that as the amount of KMnO4 in the PCL polymer pellets increased, a greater fraction of the oxidant was released over the same time period in an aqueous system. The results also indicated that the CRBP release data could be effectively modeled by a linearized diffusion model.  The gathered results could be of great use in the fields of not only engineering, but also water resource engineering sustainability, environmental science and public health.

The broader impact of the proposed research included a collaboration between two leading Historically Black College & Universities (HBCUs), FAMU and NCA&T, all of the research was conducted by students and faculty from groups traditionally underrepresented in the engineering research field.  The project supported two African American females from North Carolina A&T State University, one progressed from undergraduate to graduate work in engineering; the other published one peer-reviewed publication on the research topic, and has at least two more prepared submission, and will graduate with her Doctorate in Environmental Engineering in Summer 2021 from Florida A&M University.  In addition, six other URM Doctoral students from Florida A&M University were provided some funding support to continue research on different aspects of this project at that campus.

Overall, the project was successful in adding knowledge to the field of Environmental Engineering, as evidenced by the article publication and pending submissions with regards to the technical work of the research.  In addition, the project also broadened participation in Engineering by supporting approximately eight URM Doctoral students who are all on schedule to graduate before the end of 2023.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/24/2021
Modified by: Clayton J Clark, Ii
